Admittedly, this VN relies somewhat heavily on its massive nostalgia factor... but as a brief member of a short-lived Collegiate StarLeague team, as a dude who once chased the esports dream, and as a dude who once lived in Korea, it definitely knows how to appeal to its target audience. Nostalgia achieved. (As the postgame extra scene covers, the slight inaccuracies are mostly intentional.)

If you are, or once were, a fan of competitive StarCraft, this game is made for you. If you tried and failed to join the cutthroat world of esports, you'll appreciate it. If you're trying to understand the mind of someone who competes in video games a little better, it's worth a read. If none of these apply to you, then I question how you stumbled upon this product, but hey, it's free! 

Disclaimer to non-endemic readers: you may be confused by the way Koreans use "fighting" (in English) as a cheer, references to English commentators' excessive references, and nerdy slang for StarCraft-specific strategies.

35526770.review:
Don't be discouraged if you don't know much about e-sport, this is a very good visual novel that tackles the topic in a very relatable and outsider-friendly way, while delivering an emotionally engaging and satisfying story. It's clear that authors made it with tons of passion and really know the subject matter intimately. It also doesn’t glorify the SC2 scene, but rather focuses on the hardships and struggle that novice players face and how unforgiving it can be for those that aren’t good or disciplined enough to manage the extreme levels of competition. 

If you’re a SC2 fan like me the references to RL people and events, along with the detailed gameplay sections obviously adds extra appeal, but I think the core story is just good enough to work for someone without such knowledge. The game also provides a guide and a dictionary so people can understand the basics of both SC2 and e-sport in general, which gives it some serious educational value. 

The production values are also very decent and the length of the story (4-5 hours of relaxed reading) feels just right – it has good pacing, delivers its points clearly and end in a satisfying way. [b]If you’re a SC2 fan and didn’t play it yet – feel ashamed. If you’re not, you should try it anyways. It costs nothing and you won’t regret the time spent on reading it, especially if you’re in any way curious about the inner workings of the e-sport industry.[/b]

33823200.review:
In [i]SC2VN - The eSports Visual Novel[/i], you play as Mach (who can be either a man or a woman as you choose), an American that is currently living in Seoul, South Korea to further his/her skills as a professional video gamer. S/he is an avid player of [i]StarCraft[/i], a real-time strategy game. However, hitting it big on the [i]StarCraft[/i] scene is not easy, especially for a foreigner.

This game is a visual novel, a game that is entirely story-driven. Despite the number of choices that are offered, the game is ultimately fairly linear. I only came across one bad ending during my play, but it gave me an instant redo. I would estimate it would take around three hours to read through this.

To start off, I thought that the art in this game is pretty good. All of the background art especially is pretty detailed and nice looking. The character sprites are well-drawn and distinctive. There are only a few CGs in the game, but their quality is on par with the other art in the game.

The story is a little difficult to review. As said earlier, the main premise of this game surrounds the South Korean [i]StarCraft[/i] scene, certainly a niche subject for a visual novel. Now, I will admit that I know nothing about [i]StarCraft[/i]. [i]SC2VN[/i] includes a short introductory video for those in a similar situation, but it is extremely superficial. Because of my lack of background knowledge, I honestly had no idea what was going on during parts of the game, mainly during the actual gaming scenes. There is a glossary included that explains some fanspeak terms, but it is inadequate. If you are like me, chances are you are going to find this difficult to enjoy if you are not already familiar with [i]StarCraft[/i].

Even ignoring that issue, I found the story to be rather boring. It mostly boils down to characters talking about [i]StarCraft[/i], characters playing [i]StarCraft[/i], and some side story about Mach recruiting [i]StarCraft[/i] players to form a team. The characters themselves are another frustration with this game. They pretty much run the gamut from boring to annoying. The main character, Mach, for example, is so obsessed with [i]StarCraft[/i] that even s/he admits at one point it is difficult for him/her to talk to people about anything else. How does such a broken person even function? The other characters are the usual clichés like Jett, the tough team leader, Reva, the Spock-like analytical one who only speaks in technical language, and Stunt, the overly obnoxious teenager that already thinks he is the best. There is hardly a likable or interesting character in the game.

Overall, though the art is quite good, other aspects of this game fall short with a boring story and weak characters. Perhaps fans of [i]StarCraft[/i] or eSports might get some enjoyment out of this, but if you are clueless on those subjects it is best to skip this one.

32463265.review:
I'm going to try really hard to write an unbiased review here as I know the writer for this novel personally, but everything I write here will be an honest representation of my thoughts on the game. But first, some minor background to the expectations I had.


I've been playing visual novel games for several years. In a similar comparison, I've also played JRPGs for years. On that note, there exists a well-known engine called RPGmaker that has slowly built itself a notorious reputation in the world of game development. What I mean to say is: most RPGmaker games are middling (which is the nice way of putting it).

Most does not mean all. Likewise, I've been around the block with the world of VNs (which is largely a dark and esoteric extension of the anime fandom); there exists a similar engine created called Ren'Py that largely opened up the accessibility of VN creation; particularly on the international front. 

On that note, there are a great many Ren'Py novels that are... not great. Let me be clear that creating a VN of any proportion is an incredible feat. It requires a great many resources just to make something complete, many of which may not be accessible to most typical indie developers. That being said; VNs are not exactly a thriving business in the west due to low demand and serious quality control.

To create something memorable is an extreme challenge and worthy of praise. Sorry for all the exposition, here's what you actually came for:


SC2VN is unique for its subject matter, but does not immediately differentiate itself outside of its setting. The strongest part of this novel is easily its readability and pacing. It is just the right length for a kinetic novel, the kind that doesn't offer meaningful choices and generally reaches a singular ending. The story quickly identifies key characters and differentiates them enough to stand out in the player's mind. 

While it does not necessarily offer the most original or in-depth story, what really draws you in is how seamlessly the novel ties realistic reprsentations of the Korean eSports scene with meaningful plot progression. It is made to be very easily followed along, even for the casual reader. Whether you are an enthusiast of Starcraft or completely oblivious to the franchise, the writing easily carries the player along and allows you to enjoy even the more exclusive concepts of its theming.

To make things even easier, it even comes with an in-game glossary to offer definition for jargon and some Korean vocabulary used throughout the novel. This is a really nice feature.

A powerful thing to make your VN really stand out is good presentation. Small attention to detail, especially in GUI, can make a huge difference in my experience. SC2VN applies this concept quite well; one of the nicer touches is how character names (and their appearances to an extent) are color coded to increase distinction from one another. On top of this, an especially nice touch is how there is a small icon next to the names that identify the race that each character plays. Even tiny things like this can go a really long way!

The standard features of a typical VN engine apply, thanks to Ren'Py's great versatility. You have your history log, easily accessible by scrolling up with the mouse wheel. Main menu is right click by default, mostly just the intuitive stuff you'd come to expect from reading PC novels. You think I wouldn't have to mention this stuff, but then you'd be wrong. A lot of Ren'Py novels keep the default options like having to scroll through previous text one block at a time. For perspective: even Key's 'Little Busters' does text history like this. That novel is the GOAT, but holy-muh-convenience dude. Having an actual log come up that you can leisurely scroll through and cancel at any time is doing it right, plain and simple.

No event skip/navigation menu, but this is a superfluous feature for a novel of this length. For the most part, save states are more than enough to secure and recall your favorite scenes if you are inclined to do so.

The visuals and sound are an influential part of this medium. The musical score doesn't sound at all out of place, but it isn't all too memorable. It does borrow tracks and SFX directly from Starcraft, which is a great thematic element. The character art and backdrops exceed the par for quality in indie novels. While it's not the type of work you'd jump to frame on your desktop, it's more than enough to promote the game and appeal its presentation. The art style is also fairly distinctive from your typical 'moe bishojo meta' spam, which is refreshing to say the least.

I've been mainly positive so far, which is intentional because the novel is good. While I definitely recommend it, there are faults that I'm more than willing to address.

The plot is probably the weakest part of the novel. The characterization is fantastic, but I have little to say regarding 
the actual story. In the novel's climax, it unwittingly spirals into a very clichéd scenario between the two rival factions. There are some character tropes established throughout, but it would be unfair to criticize this without nitpicking as archetyping is a fairly common approach nowadays (why fix what isn't broken?). Despite this slight defect, the novel promotes itself off of its theme alone, which it does very effectively. An honest glimpse into the Korean pro Starcraft scene makes this more than worth the read on its own.

Choices are strewn throughout, but are more to elicit player interaction than any sort of actual influence on the game's outcome. I'd say this is a plus and a minus, because it serves its purpose well (it explains Starcraft to you. T H E M I N G B O Y S). It is simply not a gratifying way to present choices that the player can easily reload and correct, leading to what becomes more of a roadblock than actual gameplay.

Finally, the length is just okay. Keep in mind that this is a free to play game, so that says a lot. You can complete the read in about 2-5 hours, depending on how meticulous you are. For some, this can be a negative. You could say, it's too short. Finishing the novel is quick, but then it feels like a letdown when you find out that its over. Of course, being short means that the chances of you actually finishing the novel are extremely high, which is a very strong feature in the VN market. It also cuts out a lot of the obligatory 'filler' you see in a lot of Japanese VNs. It's important to note that this game isn't a dating sim, so the construction and focus is quite different. It would simply be nice to prolong the experience, but such is the reality of indie content.


Overview:

Presentation - A+

Music/Art - B+

Story - C+

Characters/Setting - A

+ Strong thematic elements throughout.
+ Memorable characters.
+ Unique Design
+ It costs the low low price of "nothing but your time."

+- Length
+- Depth of plot. It's effective and realistic, though. Satisfying conclusion.

- Obligatory choice gameplay.
- Shallow route deviations.

Overall, this is probably one of the best indie VNs I've ever read by a long shot. It's a very impressive offering, and I'm looking forward to seeing what the sequel has in store (Yes, there is a [pre]quel in development. Look up "Don't Forget Our eSports Dream"). A great glimpse into the Starcraft eSports culture in a clean, easy to digest visual novel format. 

Apologies for the long review. If you made it this far, congratulations.

And if you haven't read SC2VN yet, then what are you waiting for? It's free, buddy.

31325828.review:
A very well designed Visual Novel which is tailored to but not limited to Starcraft II players as well as eSports fans in general, however, it is done in a manner that allows it to be played by even those that are not in either of these categories.

You follow in the life of Mach, a protagonist who is trying to make his own as a competitive StarCraft II player, the art-work is clean and top-notch, as well as the overall background sound doing a good job of maintaining itself constant to the atmosphere of what's going on, the story is immersive, and the characters are well fleshed out, detailed and allow yourself to relate to them in the situations that transpire over the course of the game.

I have no real complaints, it is definitely worth your time and a good addition to your library, it's completely free and a very good Visual Novel, a lot better than some of the paid ones on the Steam platform, only really losing to them in the amount of playtime that it provides, but given that it is a freebie, it's to be expected, nonetheless the game still gives you a fairly good amount of time playing it, easily over an hour+ if you take your time reading every line, as well as tuning in to the extras that the game holds for you. 

This game is well deserving of a sequel, and i recommend it to anyone whether you be a hardcore gamer or someone who's simply looking for a Visual Novel to read out.

Despite this, I really, really, loved this game. In short, it's simply beautifully made. Yes, you are not given a lot of choices (to be honest you're barely given any), but the story alone makes it worth it. Dialogue, characters, storyline, everything is great and will soon get you hooked. Unfortunately, the story is short, about 4 hours, which will probably leave you wanting for more, and will definitely not bore you. 

I liked the story as it gave you some insight on the world of esports in South Korea, the country of esports. Also talks about how hard it is for a top player to find a team, how hard it is for someone to actually make a team even if with the right players. 

Not having played SC before hasn't made it less enjoyable (well, probably a bit, but not too much). There were some jokes, strategies, unit names etc., that I didn't understand or I had to Google (liquipedia helped A LOT, by the way), but in the end the experience was still very positive. The parts with SC games are very well explained and easy to understand. I even found myself actually panting during the last part of the game!

As it's also a free game, so I'd recommend everyone who's up for a good story and no gameplay to play this visual novel!

30069895.review:
[/h1] TL:DR (Could contain slight implications of spoilers)
            This feels like a game that I should've paid to play*. SC2VN is a great VN (Visual Novel), but unfortunately isn't much of a game in my opinion (ironic really, considering how its about esports). There are only a handful of choices that affect the games, but I feel the game compensates and even rises above those cons.
[*]The artwork and art style is amazing; Beautiful, detailed, and very comfortable to look at.
[*] The music was pretty decent, not something to brag about, but definitely nothing I can complain about.
[*] Like I said earlier, gameplay isn't that big of a factor, but does enough to make me feel like Im actually controlling what happens; Though I'd appreciate more choices in future games.
[*] The story is actually pretty great, Its shockingly accurate and realistic. There's intense tension during practices, fun jabs between characters like they've been friends their whole lives, some hints of romance, vengengeful rivalries, dramatic actions, stressful turning points, and strategic but friendly "hang outs".
          
(*Though about eSports, don't be afraid of missing something. Theres a ~2-3 minute "tutorial" about the background of eSports in the main menu; I mean theres even a damn Glosasary in-game if you miss anything. Regardless, its made to be comfortable and understandable by everyone: StarCraft fan, basic gamer, VN activist, or just any regular ol' joe.)

Overall I'd rate a 9/10. Only reason its not a 10/10, is the "game" is way too short. I uinderstand its a relatively small developer team with limited resources and such conditions, and granted it took me ~4 hours to finish, but it ended right where the story was getting good;  right when you felt invincible, already subconsiously thinking "Oh man oh man, now I gotta practice. Oh! what are we going to do now? Are we going to become famous? Can't wait to tell everyone back home. Should I talk to Mr. Yeon and thank him?". But as you finish processing what just happened, you come to a slow, but sad realization: the game's already over and the credits are running. Like, DAMN!  

But anyway: 9/10 for outstanding characters (woo Reva <3), beautiful art style, intriguing, passionate, and relatable storyline, and great execution making it an enjoyable and understandable game for anyone to purge in.

24231967.review:
As a girl and non-Starcraft player, I tried playing this to see if it would:
1) manage to hold my interest;
2) teach me more about Starcraft in an entertaining manner.

It didn't.

I lasted 30 minutes before utter boredom took over and I decided enough was enough.

The game does try to accommodate and ease in non-Starcraft people with an introductory video at the start. However, it doesn't tell you much - just a general overview of Starcraft's goals, and how Korean Starcraft players are the best in the world. Nothing is said about game tactics, skills involved, what exactly about Starcraft has made the game so popular, etc etc.

As the story progresses, you can click on certain gaming jargon (e.g. "brood wars", "GG", "PC bang", etc) within the story text, to see their explanation in a glossary. I stopped bothering with this after a while as it got tedious.

The story itself was really humdrum - you are a foreigner who's come to Korea to join a Starcraft tourney. You are filled with self-doubt and apprehension, since as a non-Korean you are already at a disadvantage. And so on. The usual. You know.

You keep clicking [i][b](there's no auto mode too)[/b][/i] until you have to make a choice. Choices are usually about what you would do in a Starcraft game against an opponent. 

Other story characters include: the expert player who's modest & forgiving; the hardened girl gamer with an undiscovered soft side; the cold-hearted trash-talking villain... [i]*rolls eyes*[/i]

The game isn't badly-made with regards to production, but plotwise it's just so very predictable and stereotypical, with your usual cookie cutter characters.

It also failed to make me understand or [i]want to[/i] understand more about Starcraft. I thought I could learn more about either player psychology, the obsessive cult-like training experience, battle mechanics, common strategies, etc, but I did not. The game is too focused on delivering its plot for this to happen effectively or in a manner that is coherent or engaging for a non-Starcraft person.

I'd rather have gone to Wikipedia or some other gaming website and read up about Starcraft there.

This is a linear story, as your choices make little to no outcome on the overall story (unless you're in a battle, then you can win or lose on some cases).That doesn't mean a linear story is bad. Look at The Last of Us, no one complained about the lack of a branching story.

This does capture nervousness and thrill of competitive sc2 pretty well, as well as the brutal realities of life. Once you get to a certain point in competitive gaming, its not fun anymore, as with everything else in life.

The story excludes many anime-styled deux ex machinas, with TEH POWA OF FRIENDSHIP overcoming all obstacles. I was overjoyed to find it missing. A story that sticks closer to reality makes it more relatable to the audience.

Character designs and personalities were very well done. Not so over-the-top to be unrealistic, but not too subtle to make the characters seem bland.

I could've easily payed 5-7$ for this. Thank you developers. I'll be in the lookout for a season 2 kickstarter.

I haven't played much in the way of visual novels before, but this one was a pleasant introduction to the genre. Presents a simple and compelling story without resorting to (nudity/murder/otheroverusedanimetropes), and while nominally about Starcraft 2, having only played the original Starcraft everything was still perfectly understandable. Not an absolute "must play" or anything -- a few re-used backgrounds are occasionally distracting, very few actual choices, and nothing overly groundbreaking -- but it'll hold your attention for a couple hours, draw you in with a small cast of humanized characters, and give you a solid story, all for very little commitment (entirely free, not a huge dl size). 

If you're curious about visual novels (or know you like them), this one's worth a try.

22514884.review:
SC2 Visual Novel is a really entertaining and easy to read VN about a person (male or female, your choice) who moves from the US to Korea with the dreams of becoming a Starcraft 2 champion.  As someone who played Brood Wars and SC2 a ton, I have to say it was filled with feel good moments, even if some of it was a little rushed and cliché.  It is really accurate with the terminology and general demeanor of the Starcraft scene for dedicated players.  I have to admit, I felt really nostalgic reading it -- always a plus.  Because it is relatively short, the story progresses at a totally unrealistic pace, but that’s Ok in my opinion as I assumed that going in, and be considered a plus to some people who want a quick and good story

  I am really torn between Positive and Negative, but I chose to go with positive because that is a reflection of the content, however I will explain my negatives.  After reading more reviews, I learned that this game was on Kickstarter (https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/vogue/sc2vn-the-esports-visual-novel/description) and raised $8,370.  

As copied from reviewer “burning.phoenix”, here are some ways it fell short of what it promised 

1. Game will be finished in 6 months: Failed. It took 2 years
2. Game will have romance options: Failed. No romance options exist
3. Game will have multiple paths: Failed. It's an absolutely linear story
4. Game will allow you to choose training partners: Failed. There is no choice in the storyline. There are no "stats" to train.
5. Game will allow you to choose which team house to train in: Failed. There is only one team house and it's simply a backdrop to an end-of-game scene
6. Game will allow you to enter online amateur tournaments to test your character's skill: Failed. There are no tournaments in the game.

In the end I chose to give it a positive review, because in my opinion it was worthwhile and enjoyable content.  

Pros
      -	Easy to read / relatively short (1-3hrs depending on pace)
      -	Nostalgic feel
      -	Accurate terminology 
      -	Likeable characters (albeit one-dimensional)
      -	Free

Cons
      -	Situations are pretty cliché, as are characters
      -	Only about 2 choices and both were pretty inconsequential – didn’t care that much because I enjoyed reading it, but some people may want more options
      -	Failed to deliver on the Kickstarter end, which is important to me.  Hesitant to give positive review to people who don’t fulfill their end

22091956.review:
First, let me point out that this game is completely free. Not everyone will realize that right away. Second, you don't need to be familiar with StarCraft 2 at all to enjoy this Visual Novel. A great tutorial is provided at the beginning, giving the necessary knowledge about what SC2 is and how its professional scene works.

I only knew about StarCraft superficially when I began this VN. I knew that it is very big in Korea and the best pro-gamers there are as famous as rockstars, with legions of fans. I knew it was like Warcraft 3, but in a futuristic setting. I've never been a fan of RTS, MOBA or anything of the sort. Yet, I was thoroughly captivated by this VN, because it's not about StarCraft and its technicalities nearly as much as it's about being a pro-gamer in general, with all the difficulties it entails. In fact, one could go as far as to claim this is a visual novel about trying to make it big in any sport, virtual or real-life. They could have substituted SC2 for other sports and the core aspects of the story would remain the same.

The characters are well-written and the dialogue is very witty and funny at times. The character's psychological conflicts and doubts are well portrayed, and their personalities are all very different. Despite this variety, I liked every single major character, which is a difficult thing to pull off and shows how much love and hard work went into designing and writing them.

Overall, this ranks among the best VNs I've read (the best would be Katawa Shoujo, which is also free and also developed by a non-japanese team), and I highly recommend the play even if you've never heard of StarCraft. You're in for a great experience regardless. 

It's hard to believe a game of this quality is distributed for free!

22041479.review:
Individual Conclusions:

Story: 4/10 (Mediocre)

The game is 2.5-3 hours AT BEST and that should be an automatic warning sign. The story felt kind of rushed or just made on bullet points. Random nobody goes to South Korea to get good and is constantly depressed? Check. Random nobody is our PC? Check. PC finds multiple high-profile eSport gamers and gets noticed? Check. PC impresses them, despite getting SQUASHED at least 3 times IN THE SAME DAY BY 3 DIFFERENT PEOPLE? Check. PC gets high-profile person X to leave their team? Check. The story just hits bullet point after bullet point and it sucks, because it hides some interesting issues and nuances with eSports and professional gaming. (e.g.: Accel, AKA: Anime-Chill-Bro, mentions that his Brood War team was forcibly disbanded by sponsors not paying and the players couldn't pool enough dosh together to sue for damages.)

Characters: 3/10 (Bad)

Accel is an emotionless walking male cliche. Jett is the hothead bitch that hates life. Mach (the PC) is the "I regret every decision I ever make" idiot. Stunt is the brat with an ego that could rival the Milky Way Galaxy for size. Rega is the emotionless walking anonymous cliche. Bolt is basically Shadow The Edgehog, except eSports. It just hits cliched character after cliched character that make you wanna slam your head on the desk when you talk to them. Multiple times, while playing, I asked myself "Now, WHO THE HELL ARE THESE PEOPLE? We met them in PC Bangs and all of a sudden, we're acting like we're soul mates? WHAT?!"

Art: 6/10 (Fine)

Artwork's fine. Nothing to write home about. Each character has a max of 4-5 poses each.

Suspension of Disbelief Held: 3/10 (Bad)

So, let me get this straight. There are 3 HIGH-TIER PROFESSIONAL PLAYERS (Accel, Jett, AND Bolt) conveniently hanging out in the exact same PC Bang, that you just so happen to wander into (after probably passing at least 3-5 others) and they just randomly make time to talk to Mach, the random nobody? AND Jett just so happens to be bailing on her team, wanting to start one with Mach, besides only knowing him/her no more than a week?...I don't buy it.

Gameplay: N/A (No Rating)

There is none. It's a visual novel, you expected something to do besides stare at the same anime poses for 3 hours?

Overall Rating: 5/10 (Average)

Play it once and you'll likely forget about it after. Potentially entertaining with some prophetic allusions to eSports nuances and issues, but the characters are cliched, stupid, and forgettable. Not awful, but could have been more.

I hadn't played visual novels in a long time, but this was a refreshing reminder of why I used to love them in the first place. The story is very self contained, and while the subject matter, esports, may appear daunting to those unfamiliar with the scene it actually works seamlessly in the style of a Rocky tale, the underdog trying to make it in a competitive world and the struggles they face and the expectations versus reality of it all as they find their own place.
Admittedly the story may be a tad predictable as goals, hurdles and antagonists are introduced early on, but while the plot may not break new ground in terms of story telling that is in no way am issue, if you are looking for a story more concerned wtih twist reveals you wont find that here, but if you are looking for a story with a genuine love for its subject matter and more concerned with the journey than the destination this is definitely a must.
The technical values are nothing out of this world, they serve as a medium to tell the story and they do so sufficiently well, no mini games clogging up the pace of the story either, which for me is always a plus when it comes to visual novels, nice art, backgrounds and expressions all work well with the story.
Over all a really interesting game to play through and one I would definitely like to see more of in the future.

21789982.review:
Another free visual novel, but this is pretty damn short, but as the phrase implies: short and sweet.

The story of this visual novel is about a guy or girl (you choose the gender) who sets off to Korea in an attempt to fulfill their dream of becoming a professional starcraft player. The subject matter of this story will immediately put some people off because for some, esports isn't interesting. But trust me, this puts things into some sort of perspective that more people will understand even if some decisions you make are nonsensical to you. During Mach's journey to becoming a pro player they meet a bunch of players in the starcraft pro scene who are definitely in no way whatsoever inspired by real people and any resemblance to real people is completely coincidental. /s. These characters are all made to resemble real starcraft players. Spoilers: Mach makes it. Honestly, what did you expect? A sad ending? No. Mach makes it, but it is all about how they get there and what the future could possibly hold for Mach and the friends Mach has made.

The artwork and music in this game is ok. They have reused the same image several times in different locations but nothing that significant. For a free visual novel, I didn't expect much else. It isn't terrible which is all you need to know.

Is this visual novel worth a read? Since it is so short and free, I would say it is.

I know very little about the e-sports scene, and it's been over a decade since I last collected Vespene Gas, but that wasn't a barrier here. This is a really solid story about a foreigner trying to make her (or his) way in the competative world of Starcraft 2 leagues. The characters are entertaining, the conversations sound authentic, and I really got caught up in the story.

If there's a downside it's that this is a fairly linear visual novel, rather than one of those decision tree ones. There's a few decision points, but mostly they determine what characters say to you further in the tale. Although there is at least one decision that leads to a Game Over if you choose poorly.

I thougoughly enjoyed this, and would recommend it to anyone with a cursory interest in the Korean e-sports scene. If you're already heavily into it, then I'll warily recommend, but don't blame me if the details are anachronistic or just plain wrong. (Although there is a commentary extra where they discuss some changes they made to make for a better story)

20874778.review:
SC2VN ist eine Visual Novel von Team Eleven Eleven. Inhaltlich geht es um die E-Sport Szene in Korea, insbesondere im Blick auf Starcarft und Starcraft 2. Abgesehen von zahlreichen Informationen über den Alltag der professionellen Spieler, der E-Sports Kultur und ähnlichen wurde das ganze auch noch in eine nette Story gepackt, in welcher der/die Hauptcharakter/in versucht selber ein professioneller Spieler zu werden und ein Team zu finden. Insgesamt fand ich die Story sehr gelungen und unterhaltsam. Es gibt viele amüsante Unterhaltungen, insbesondere das Trinkspiel in der Kneipe. Zudem sind die einzelnen Charaktere nicht nur relativ unterschiedlich sondern auch alle sehr glaubhaft, was die Geschichte nicht nur nachvollziehbarer sondern auch interessanter macht.
Schade finde ich allerdings, dass es relativ selten Entscheidungen zu fällen gibt und man von der Masse an Text teilweise doch ziemlich erschlagen wird. Zudem ist es bedauerlich, dass die wenigen Entscheidungen die man treffen kann keine wirklichen Auswirkungen auf den Spielverlauf haben. Lediglich 2 der etwa 7 Entscheidungen (hab nicht genau mitgezählt) bewirken ein frühzeitiges Ende, wobei man dann sofort die Option erhält kurz vor der Entscheidung neu zu starten und die richtige Wahl zu treffen.
Grafisch ist das Spiel meiner Meinung nach herausragend. Jeder Charakter sieht mühevoll und detailreich gestaltet aus. Nur die Hintergründe hätten ein paar mehr Details vertragen können, da einige doch relativ leer aussehen. Allerdings vermitteln sie einen guten Eindruck von der Lokalität, wo sich die Charaktere gerade befinden und oft wird ein Großteil des Hintergrundes ohnehin von den Charakteren verdeckt. Zudem fand ich sehr positiv, dass die Szenen die sich um die Starcraft Matches selbst drehten, nicht einfach nur beschrieben, sondern auch mit richtigen Screenshots (zumindest sah es sehr danach aus) verbildlicht wurden.
Der Sound ist ok bis gut, besonders gefallen hat mir der kurze Musiktrack vom VSL Hintergrund. Eine Vertonung der Charaktere wäre noch ganz nett gewesen hätte bei der Menge an Text sicherlich des Budget gesprengt.
Eine Anmerkung noch zum Englisch des Spiels. Dieses ist schon etwas anspruchsvoller aber jeder der ein normales Schulenglisch kann sollte klar kommen und sich das wenige was er nicht versteht anhand des Kontextes oder der Bilder erschließen können.
Insgesamt eine wirklich gute Visual Novel die ich jedem der mit dem Genre etwas anfangen kann empfhelen würde, ebenso jedem der sich mit E-Sports und/oder Starcarft beschäftigt oder sich zumindest für die Thematik interessiert, zumal es kostenlos ist.

I've never played StarCraft. I have high standards for writing. I seriously enjoyed this game. More than I thought I could have. It sets out to do exactly one thing and does it well. The characters, story and setting are simple but compelling. The game is long enough to feel like a complete experience and short enough to remain engaging. After I finished it, I found myself wanting more. 

The story works because it takes the familiar chase of a difficult dream and sets it in fresh territory, the deep and rich world of competitive E-Sports in South Korea. The setting and game are rich enough to feel like a lore all their own. As a novice to the game and scene, it was actually more interesting for me. I felt like I was discovering a fictional world... That just happened to actually exist.

Give it a download. It's well worth the time.

19860724.review:
The Visual Novel genre's answer to the film Free To Play, which is also free on Steam.

Feels more like a Kinetic Novel though, since few of your choices seem to make a significant impact.  But other VNs like Collage did something similar:  "deviant" choices will derail and end the story abruptly, but even if it isn't that interactive the story still hooked this reader in.

As someone who played Starcraft (all 'cept for Legacy of the Void), and someone who plays Go (well sort of I mean I'm hardly above 20 kyu), and an avid lover of VNs in general this game should have been right up my alley, and it's certainly worth your time, but the ending cuts off at a, well, not at a cliffhanger but at a point where one who's read up to this point might certianly want to know what happens next for these people.

You get introduced to five pro gamers, each with their own distinct personality.  Now, I wouldn't go so far as to say they're all well-developed, but hey I for one care about them!  To end the story this quickly feels like the authors plan for a sequel locked behind a pay wall!  >:)

19152731.review:
SC2VN is a light visual novel that follows your fictitious character “Mach” and his/her experience moving to Korea in an attempt to hit it big in the Star Craft 2 esports scene. From the beginning of the novel Mach is seen battling with her recent loss in a tournament qualifier and second thoughts about moving to Korea. 

Obviously there are two barriers to entry: knowledge of Korean terms and knowledge of Star Craft/esports terms. Thankfully the game has you covered on both fronts. A glossary unlocks as you read that defines advanced terminology. Additionally there is also a short introduction to what Star Craft 2 is, narrated by one of the best casters Sean “Day[9]” Plott”.

Being experienced with video games and esports the glossary was not more than a handy reminder. It will definitely be useful to the uninitiated. Though, even I found some Korean terms, not contained in the glossary, that I did not know.

This isn’t just a text document with attractive art and effects (there are some entertaining though minor effects)—there are some choices to be made. Do you choose to make an aggressive maneuver or defensive? Do you ask a character an emotional question? The options are entertaining, but happen so occasionally it left me wanting.

Overall, it’s an entertaining visual novel that had me itching to continue the story whenever I put it down. More than that, it has me wanting to get back to playing Star Craft 2 despite my horrid performance.

If you’re new to visual novels, this is an excellent place to start.
If you’re unaware of esports, this is a great place to learn.
If you’re unknowledgeable of Star Craft (2), this is a great place to pick it up.

19007998.review:
SC2VN is an emotional rollercoaster. Anyone who has tried to play any game at a competitive level will be able to relate, though most people won't have experienced circumstances like those in the story. The beautiful artwork and flawless music tie everything together to make a unique experience.
In SC2VN you follow the adventures of Mach, foreign trash extraordinaire, as he takes a probably misguided trip to South Korea to determine, once and for all, whether or not he can go pro. A couple fortuitous meetings in the local PC bang- a cyber-cafe of sorts, to make a really poor analogy- get him into much more than he bargained for.
There are two things to keep in mind: first, SC2VN is free. All it asks is your time (approximately three or four hours of it), and I think it's worth the price. The characters aren't the most complex, most of them seeming fairly archetypal, but they're fun to hang out with and have nice dialogue, anecdotes and backstory tidbits. The antagonist didn't strike me as being very realistic, though, even compared to the protagonists. However, the rollicking, fourth wall-breaking extra material unlocked after finishing the story gives a bit of justification for his... intensity.
Second, note that as far as I can tell (after one playthrough) the VN is completely on rails. There's a couple choices that affect dialogue (maybe a few more than I give it credit for, come to think of it), but none of them do much. Further, [spoiler]a bit of tinkering reveals that Mach is guaranteed to lose his first two matches, and while winning the third is possible, failing to do so counts as losing the game and simply requires the player to go back and pick the right option. As for the fourth, I think failure is an option there as well, though just in the 'game over' sense.[/spoiler] Finally (big spoiler coming up), a certain set of options is fake. [spoiler]The opponent is guaranteed to strike first, before a choice is made, and Mach is guaranteed to win the set. Initially I thought it was a neat quicktime event- at this point Mach is facing a veteran who wants to stomp him, after all- but quickly picking an option simply led to the same events. Amusingly, the timer was still active, causing the sequence to restart a second or so in. Considering the reader is allowed to fail elsewhere,[/spoiler] I found this unacceptable. If you ask me, it's the VN's single great failing- though if one isn't bothered by the story's overall lack of choice this statement is high praise, considering what else could have gone wrong.
All in all, while SC2VN is much more something one reads than plays, its wonderful atmosphere and fun, inspiring story more than make up for its shortcomings.
"Strive to win, Mach. Not to not lose."

18994379.review:
Grills don't play Starcraft

Immersion Borken. 0/10

[strike] >tfw no qt3.14 progamer gf to play vidya with[/strike]

In all seriousness, SC2VN is a decent little VN that's also available for the grand old price of zero dollars. I enjoyed my time in it and I didn't waste any money so why the negative review?

Because this game raised 8000$ on Kickstarter to deliver a VN that can be finished in around 3 hours that's completely 100% linear. Two choices in the game lead to a bad end and every other choice has almost no bearing on the story. The two choices take place during the SC2 battles where you select your strategy, and the game often has these "battles" that seem to be a sort of minigame (You get a popup regarding the known info of your opponent and his strategies) but they're literally SC2 screenshots with a single choice in the middle. Two of these choices don't matter and the other two have a possibility of a game over. The very final battle of the game was hyped up in the story with a lot of the characters giving you tips, info and advice to use against your opponent. I thought it was gonna be a multiple choice strateg-a-thon and took notes so I can remember all the info.

In the end, there was absolutely no choice whatsoever in the game's ultimate clash, contrary to nearly every main match up to that point. The game ends just as you become a full fledged pro gamer. (ie when you think it's about to get good)


That disappointment was the final motivation to write this review.The game promised so much more during kickstarter, it was almost gonna be [i]Pro Gamer Simulator 2015[/i] but it delivers on not a single promise:

1. Game will be finished in 6 months: Failed. It took 2 years
2. Game will have romance options: Failed. No romance options exist
3. Game will have multiple paths: Failed. It's an absolutely linear story
4. Game will allow you to choose training partners: Failed. There is no choice in the storyline. There are no "stats" to train.
5. Game will allow you to choose which team house to train in: Failed. There is only one team house and it's simply a backdrop to an end-of-game scene
6. Game will allow you to enter online amatuer tournaments to test your character's skill: Failed. There are no tournaments in the game.

There's no reason in 2015 to take 8000$ and deliver what is essentially a free fan made game made in a free VN engine.

Katawa Shoujo was made with literally Zero dollars by a bunch of autists on 4chan and each of that game's multiple paths is longer and deeper in every way than SC2VN's single one.

So really, the best thing I can say about this game is: It's free and a decent waste of a couple of hours.

This was the first visual novel game I've ever played. Before I played this game I had a generally negative view of VNs. However, I also played starcraft and playing a VN that was about something I enjoyed also allowed me to give this game a chance.

The story is overall, very well crafted and thought out. Character development is good, and the game avoids useless sideplots and instead takes interesting paths in developing the main plot and the characters along the way. No character is wasted, or simply exists to fill some hole in the story. Each and everyone of them has a purpose and represents the many different backgrounds that Starcraft players come from.

It also reveals the amount of hardwork and drama that goes on in the professional esports scene. It's not all glamour and fun. There's hardwork involved, and just as much luck and fate as well. Some make it, but many do not. Overall one gets to see that it is a serious industry with serious people with serious dreams no lesser than your own. They have many of the same challenges that we face, like disapproving family, stiff competition, self-doubt, and uncertain futures. But it also shows us that with hardwork and supportive friends anything is possible.

I had fun playing this VN and I definitely learned alot. It also renewed my love for Starcraft and I can't wait to increase my own understanding and skills in the game. I highly encourage those who love esports to give this VN a go!

18833988.review:
Визуальная новелла о профессиональных [strike] задротах [/strike] игроках в StarCraft 2.

В начале новеллы предусмотрена краткая вводная для тех кто не в курсе что такое Старкрафт (хотя есть ли такие среди любителей компьютерных игр?), озвученная известным комментатором Шоном "Day[9]" Плоттом. В игре есть 2 фишки которые в визуальных новеллах практически не встречаются -  1) это выбор персонажа (девушки или парня), который влияет разве что на обращение к главному герою - "здорово чувак!", "привет девчонка", и на 2-3 сцены где показан главный герой, 2) глоссарий в котором указаны термины из мультиплеера в Стракрафте.

В игре хорошая рисовка как задников, так и персонажей, в сценах где идут соревнования, задники заменяются скриншотами из Старкрафта. Музыка в игре легкая и она ИМХО практически не заметная. Язык в новелле английский, тем кто рубился по мультиплееру в "старик", тем будет проще ибо термины на русском, один фиг калька с английского.

Из минусов - отсутствие кнопочки для пролистывания прочитанного текста, и отсутствие галереи.

В принципе новелла может понравиться и людям далеким от Старкрафта и киберспорта, ибо половину сюжета идут размышления о трудностях на пути к своей мечте, о важности команды, о дружбе, и прочих важных вещах. Но вот вторую половину идут описания матчей по Старкрафту, причем написанные как будто с реальных матчей. Так что большее удовольствие от игры будет гарантированно все же тем кому Старкрафт и\или киберспорт близки.

8 зерг-рашей из 10.

18667849.review:
Well worth a few hours of your time, this free Visual Novel is a great peek into the sorts of challenges facing someone looking to become a professional gamer. There's some concessions of realism for the sake of story, but they don't hinder the game in any real way, and I found myself actually interested and even caring for/about the characters.

The interface is clean and responsive, and the medium is put to good use, as there's little things that happen, like interruptions which wouldn't be possible with a non-interactive book. Do note, however, that while you do get to make a few decisions here and there, this is less of a game than an experience, so the emphasis is on telling the tale of Mach and his/her journey. That's standard for many VNs, but it has to be noted, because this is a genre that will be new to many players.

I personally feel it's a better experience with the female protagonist, as then the issues of discrimination and sexism are more relevant, as well as some of the bonds formed between characters feeling more true to life,  but it's not heavy-handed with either player choice. Although fictional, there's quite a bit of historic fact and character traits based off real people included, so, in a way, SC2VN is educational as well.

Recommended for anyone interested in eSports, StarCraft, gaming in general, or just a few hours of reading and enjoyment.

18659748.review:
Some games roll around each year with the inevitability of Christmas or the X Factor. Another year, another Call of Duty, an Assassin's Creed. Yet this year isn't just like any other for the world's favourite console football game. Most obviously, it's the first where EA Canada has really got to grips with Steam, resulting in a mass of changes to the graphics and animation engines. Some are merely cosmetic, and some so subtle as to be almost unnoticeable, but many have a genuine impact on the gameplay.

Less obviously, SC2VN 5 seems to have moved away from the focus on ball control and the defensive game of SC2VN 3 and SC2VN 4, and towards a more dynamic, aggressive and - frankly - exciting style of play. If you played the last two  SC2VNs tired of getting mired in the midfield, bored witless by the slow, methodical pace, then you'll probably find this year’s SC2VN the best since the glory days of SC2VN 2. It's still a game built by people hell-bent on reflecting every aspect of the beautiful game, but this time they’ve remembered that SC2VN can also be fun. 

Structurally, it's pretty much identical to FIFA. The single-player campaign remains dominated by Career mode, where you can take either a player or a manager through several seasons, hoping to take your team to league and tournament success, or build a fantastic national and international career.

It's still basically a combination of the old Be a Pro and Be a Manager modes, where you roll through the season playing matches, dodging or accepting loan and transfer requests and getting the odd rollicking for your behaviour on the pitch, and as before, you can choose whether to play matches from the viewpoint of just the one player or play with the whole team. The latter will be most people's choice, but playing in just the one position can be interesting, really making you think about where you need to be and what you need to do to make the most of every opportunity, while creating opportunities for others.

This game is also a First Person Shooter, like Call of Duty, or Counter Strike, even Skyrim with guns. The only downside is that you have too kill a dog to progress, and that is the only flaw with this game. I rate this game a 9/11

"... I came to Korea Because I want to play in the VSLI Because I want to be a champion." Mach

SC2VN is a great visual novel, for it free price you can spend about 3 hours reading the story. In my opinion, its even beat the [spoiler] Gender Bender DNA Extreme visual novel[/spoiler] effort.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Like any other free visual novel, its story is not that long and it can be continue by it sequel. But I am very impressed how they manage the animation, zooming on some image, it really bring some curiosity on the image or a nice break from clicking. The story is about a guy/girl (depending which you choose from) from a failure at MOBA (multiplayer online battle arena) to a champion. Though the story is not that finished, you will be satisfied by the ending. 

[h1]Music[/h1]
The music in this game is a really great mood changer from being funny, serious, or even awkward. Even though sometime the music cant match the situation (especially at awkward time), It's still a catchy song, oh and the ending music in my opinion is the best.

[h1]Art[/h1]
The art are the most impressive thing I have seen in visual novel lately, though sometime the art of character model changes on some screen. I admire the Korean City drawing and sky from above, and some enviroment are really detailed which make this visual novel stands out from other visual novel.

Conclusion
+ Great art, enviroment and character, many sprite too
+ Music is fun to hear
+ A Great Story driven game
- Some music dont match the mood
- Some scene change the character model

MUST TRY

18371603.review:
SC2VN is exactly what you imagine it will be by its title a StarCraft 2 Visual Novel and it doesn't disappoint.

Anyone who considers themselves a gamer can empathize with the MC, everyone of us have felt the sting of a loss but it's what we do afterwards that truly defines us. The story is great and captures eSports better than most sports commentator can hope to achieve.

eSports will always be looked down on by the masses but the pursuit of such a dream is just as viable as a; musician, actor, profesional athlete, or any conventional or unconventional job. eSports deserves as much credit as any of these and I feel this game emodies that statement.

Sure this isn't your conventional VN where you have multiple women/men to romance with several routes to venture down but it is true to its source and what gamer truly expects a VN focused around gaming to have a lot of romance? Maybe it didn't have as much routes or choices that I have come to expect in a VN but it told a great story, without a defined MC gender mind I add.

All in all, I enjoyed my time playing this game and I hope everyone else who did give this game a look at enjoyed it too. You did a great job with this game and I hope to see more projects from you guys in the future.

This is technically about a pro-gamer trying to make it in Korea, but it really is a tale about the finding the dedication to pursue dreams.  You don't need to know too much about high level Starcraft play to enjoy the game, but you do need to have some interest or you'll be bored more often than not.

Two downsides.  First, like some other visual novels, there aren't too many fail states; this isn't a problem per se, but it is kinda weird that you can get a bad ending by losing certain Starcraft matches along the way, but you can't lose by giving up and moving back home.  Second, the game feels like a bit like the prologue and chapter 1 of a full novel: in the good ending the main character is now a pro-gamer, but there are so many more stories to tell about the cast of characters, and I really want to see where their full careers go.

Here's hoping for a sequel.

18262763.review:
Just finished the game yesterday and this game got me mesmerized from the start to finish. Note : I do not understand Starcraft and frankly I did not play this game to understand SC2, I only played because I waanted to have an insight about the life of a professional eSports player, so I will not talk about the SC2 aspects in this review.

Well anyway, here goes my review :

This game tells the story about Mach, a foreign player from the West (maybe USA) who came to Korea to 'play Starcraft' and go professional. Throughout the course of the game, it told you how a professional eSports player creates a team and how they interacted/practised with their teammates (the game mainly focus on this), how the players' emotional condition affects their motivation, and what was required to succeed in eSports asides from talent and skill. I really think the game captures and retell those moments to the player perfectly and I do believe these process were similiar to some (if not most) professional eSports player's experience, I think it really gives you insight about competitive gaming life and how uneasy it is to live as an eSports player. 

However, the game is not without it flaws though. There were moments that the game made seems very easy (which I was sceptical) :
1. The first was when Mach got scouted by Accell a renowned pro player. He instatenously agreed to play against him after watching him played one game, oh boy how would I love to be able to got scouted so easy like that and become a pro player also :O

2. Accell, Jett, Stunt and Reva seems to settle in with their team very quickly and looked very motivated. They literally became 'close friends' who trusted each other within one week since the team were established. Trust me, it is very rare to find a player who is not only skilled, but motivated and full of commitment, let alone being able to trust each other within that short amount of time.

All in all, it is a good VN that worth reading and you would not regret trying it out since it's also free. Like the others reviewer stated, I too would gladly pay for any sequel the devs may release in the future. I highly recommend this game.

18261307.review:
Alle, die noch daran zweifeln, dass kostenlose Spiele gut sein können, sollten SC2VN - The eSports Visual Novel spielen.
Der Stil mag sicherlich nicht jedem gefallen, und wer allgemein kein Fan von Visual Novels ist, wird hiermit wahrscheinlich auch nicht glücklich. Für mich aber war es einer der besten, die ich bis jetzt gespielt habe.
Kurzgefasst geht es um den Versuch eines ausländischen Starcraft 2 Spielers, seine Fähigkeiten in Korea zu verbessern und sich so einen Namen zu machen. Es gefällt mir, dass man zu Beginn die Wahl des Geschlechts hat.
Alle Charaktere hatten ihre eigene Persönlichkeit, sodass man sich bereits nach kurzer Zeit mit ihnen verbunden gefühlt hat. Spielerisch sollte man natürlich hier nichts Neues erwarten. Auch hier dürfen wir ab und zu Entscheidungen treffen, die manchmal eher irrelevant, manchmal aber auch das Ende bestimmen können. 
Abgesehen davon haben mir das Menü- und Backgrounddesign sowie die ausgewählten Soundtracks gut gefallen.
Ein kleiner Bug scheint die gespeicherte Spielzeit zu sein: In meinem Profil steht jetzt etwa 1,5 Stunden, aber insgesamt sollten sich etwas mehr als 3 Stunden gesammelt haben. Ansonsten gab es aber keinerlei Probleme. Dennoch würde ich hier empfehlen, oft zu speichern, da ich mir nicht sicher bin, ob die automatische Speicherfunktion auch vor Spielabstürzen einsetzt. Einen Pluspunkt möchte ich noch für die freischaltbaren Entwicklerkommentare geben, die ein paar interessante Hintergrundinformation parat haben. Da lässt sich über fehlende Sammelkarten und Errungenschaften schnell hinwegsehen.
Letztentlich bestimmt ihr, ob Mechs Traum nur Wunschdenken war oder der erste Schritt zur Verwirklichung ist.
Und keine Sorge: Ich denke, dass auch Leute, die total unerfahren in eSports und Starcraft sind, sich schnell mithilfe des Glossars zurechtfinden werden. Nur ein wenig Englischkenntnisse wären von Vorteil, da zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt keine deutsche Lokalisierung vorhanden ist. Alles in allem fand ich die Story und Erzählweise hervorragend inszeniert und würde mich sehr auf eine Fortsetzung (bitte mit den gleichen Charakteren!) freuen.

18257036.review:
TL;DR I'd pay for a sequel, WHEN they start accepting any donations for it. *fingers crossed*

Gameplay: It's a visual novel, press SPACE or ENTER to proceed. Use the scroll-up mousewheel to view text if you accidentally skip it. The choices don't have much impact save for a few 'dead ends' but judicious use of their save system makes this a minor gripe at best and allows you to view the different 'routes'.

Story: For a visual novel, you'd expect this to be pretty damn important. Good news, it is. The characters are likeable, the 'villains' are detestable, and everybody has something at stake. The sacrifices they made to pursue their dreams rings true with me, and helps me cheer the main character (you) and his team on to victory. All their suffering, all their flaws, turns them into real underdogs that are desperately clawing for a dream where they may achieve happiness and validation in their lives. There are also bits and pieces of South Korean culture mixed in there plus a helpful glossary for terms about SC2 e-sports that you may not know at first.

Music: Background-variety music, sets the right mood, gets the job done, nothing spectacular here. Don't expect Hans Zimmerman-levels of epic quality.

Graphics/Art: Passable. The characters look nice enough although the girls really look like the guys, and makes me wonder if they cut corners by making male characters first then 'rounding them out' giving them slightly more hair to make them into girls. Most of the backgrounds are re-used, and not surprising for a game that is free.

I will rob banks if it means their sequel gets funded. Lock 'n Load, people.

18250280.review:
When I went into this game, I expected it to be sort of like Katawa Shoujo, but with StarCraft, and less sad. Instead, what I got was genuinely good writing, with good visuals, and a great story. As a fan of eSports, it was interesting to get insight into the more human aspects. Let me break it down a bit. 

The writing. It was really good. Characters were believable and likeable. The dialogue conveyed what was meant to be brought across. 

The visuals. The game looked nice. I'm somewhat a fan of the style used here, and the backrounds looked great.

The story. Without giving away too much, it follows a upstart SC2 player who travels to South Korea in hopes of making it big in the pro-gaming scene. It was really interesting, and I found myself invested in what it told. One complaint though is that it was over a bit fast, and the ending leaves a bit to be desired. However, a sequel is apparently a possibilty, so I hope that is the case.

Overall, this is a surprisingly good game, and I definitely recommend it to fans of VN's and really anyone who looks for a good narrative.

18216218.review:
First of all - I usually do not write reviews but I believe this game deserves every bit of attention as it may inspire Devs to come up with a sequel in near future (at least I hope).

Let me put it this way: I pretty much hate VN and I really enjoyed this one. I also don't like eSports in general and this game made me interested in competitive Starcraft. It is truly remarkable how this simple game kept me both invested in story and relaxed at the same time. The idea was there for quite some time but until now I didn't see someone take it and make into a story of a game. Shame as this one proves that eSports make fantastic topic for "social story".

It is hard to critique this game, I mean, come on - its FREE. Devs don't have any profits from it. However as I both enjoyed it and was disappointed by some parts, I would like to offer some feedback which may lead to improvement of this one or the sequel (which of course WILL BE RELEASED SOON, RIGHT? RIGHT?!).

[Small spoilers may occur after this point]
Pros:
+ way more natural dialogues that in typical VN
+ diverse and likeable characters
+ great way to learn about competitive Starcraft
+ simple but involving story about trying to get into eSports
+ quite realistic vision of Korean society and eSports community (for a noob like me at least)
+ assets form Starcraft 1 (that music!)
+ nice graphic
+ nice music
+ short (for some)
+ lack of romance (for some)
+ IT'S FREE

Cons:
- lots of graphic and music assets re-use
- lack of meaningful choices (and choices in general)
- lack of different endings
- lack of main character self-development
- some characters and scenes are really cliché
- short (for me) - it ends right where the real story begins
- lack of romance (for me... I mean some! Not me. Some.)
- minor bugs

FINAL NOTE: 7/10

The game is doing what it does very well bearing the fact that it is crowd-funded and given for free. I feel bad that I didn't hear about it and didn't back it up when Kickstarter was on. But I really hope that Devs will come back with the sequel - longer and better in all the ways I listed and those I didn't notice. This time I will be there to back them up.

Fighting!

18181012.review:
A very basic visual novel with decent visuals and simple but good storyline. It's a VN that's mostly reading and little gameplay. Don't expect meaningful choices. It's pretty mediocre as a VN but is somewhat special because it deals with a topic not used so much (esports/SC2) rather than generic school life.

After recently playing Telltale's Walking Dead I can't help but feel how unsatisfying this storyline is. There is no branching, no twists, just conversation options that either don't matter or immediately lead to a game over. I don't expect the same quality but was hoping for at least a little depth. I doubt they'll continue developing this but at the very least it would've been nice to have multiple people to recruit (and see changes based on who you recruit).

You can choose gender for the main character but (as they say) it only affects character appearance and every once in a while dialogue is added (that has no impact on the game). The SC2 ingame pictures were a very nice (and necessary) addition to help show the action moments. They also threw in a random fanservice hot springs pic in the extras which was unnecessary but I think many people will enjoy and expect from a VN.

[quote]This game is written for all players who want to live the dream. No previous knowledge of StarCraft and eSports required.[/quote]
They have a Day[9] do a quick skit and glossary that helps a little but I do think you need previous knowledge to really enjoy and understand everything that goes on in the VN. It's also very useful to know the basics of SC2 which are glossed over in the VN (unit names/purposes, building names/purposes, basic strategies). Otherwise it could be hard to follow the actual SC2 action. One example line: "My hellions make a beeline for his natural expansion's worker line". I'd recommend watching Day[9]'s old introductory videos (not the extra skit) if you don't know at least that much.

It also helps a lot to know common shortcuts of visual novel games because it doesn't mention anything in-game (like R-click for menu/back, ctrl/tab for skip, mouse scroll up for chat log and more). You can find out a lot by pressing random keys on your keyboard and hoping for the best (that it doesn't exit out/quickload and ruin your progress).

I couldn't figure out the purpose of red text until I randomly noticed the glossary on the ingame menu late in my playthrough (and it doesn't show up on the main menu). I tried hovering over the word and right/left clicking it and gave up. It turns out a couple minutes into the game they had one line of text drop down on the top of the screen that explained how to check the glossary (and it only remained for that one line of dialogue). I didn't notice it because I was reading the dialogue at the bottom and clicked past it. 

Despite its flaws it's worth a look if you have any interest in Starcraft or esports. The theme might be enough to carry the game because there aren't many alternatives.

18178452.review:
If you don't like Visual Novels, and have never heard of/care about Starcraft or eSports in general this won't be one to change your mind, but it may teach you a few things about the scene. I just can't promise you'll enjoy your time learning.

If you do like VNs, but not SC2/eSports, give it a try. It's a thoroughly charming, well written and surprisingly dramatic take on a part of gaming most people never get a look at. 

If you like Starcraft 2, but have never tried/do not like VNs, it'll cost you two hours of your time and I found enough amusing references and in-jokes to the scene to keep me smiling all the way through. It's worth a look for those alone(especially the extras scenes.)

If you like Starcraft and VNs... why are you still reading? Play it. You will not be disappointed.

Spoliers ahead: As someone with a somewhat in-depth knowledge of SC2, I did find a few things that bugged me. Some of the stuff mentioned was not really relevant anymore in SC2, talking specifically about mechanics and the like, and I was kind of disappointed that you couldn't make any significant choices in the final showdown... but the story was well enough told it had me biting my nails at the very end. Remember, the premise is that only about 2% of people who try to break into eSports make it at all... but some do make it. 

I also like how, if you pick a female Mach, it does touch on some of the issues faced by female progamers that their male counterparts don't have to deal with... but does so very even-handedly, without being crusading or in-your-face about it. I honestly wish it would have touched a bit more on the true toxicity of the community at times, but I can understand how the authors wanted to go with a more positive approach to things. All in all, I'm definitely looking forward to/hoping for a sequel.

18164329.review:
Knowing nothing about Starcraft or eSports (in its current form, at least), getting into this was still really easy. There was a slight bit of novelty starting out, but from there, everything about it was really intriguing and built in a way to keep you reading.

The story is written by someone who definitely sounds like they know what they're talking about, in terms of culture and gaming. This can result in it being a bit hard to grasp at times, but there's still a lot of genuine writing and emotion, and not just someone writing about video games because they think it's "cool" or "hip". The characters as well are written in a sincere way, not coming off as caricatures or stereotypes, but as actual human beings.  There's nuance and layering to them.

The way the story paces itself is also done in a smart manner. There's not too much dumping of exposition and action, yet you don't stall in the story for too long as well. It's a great way to get you accompanied with the setting, the characters, and the playing field as well. And, as an aside and small bonus, you can pick whether you play as a male or female protaganist, which doesn't change the story much (and if it does, it's not too noticeable).

Which is another good thing about this game! Occasionally, you get to play in some mock Starcraft 2 battles,  Rather than actually controlling the battles yourself, you're given action trees to decide which way the story goes and how the characters react. What help is that these options are rarely designed to make you super awesome or unbeatable; they're how a player who's in a bit too over their heads would think and react. The game and story, then, doesn't require you to be a hardcore fan of SC2 or eSports to really get it. You can start right out of the gate and still feel connected with everything.

There are a couple drawbacks though. The first one only really applies if you don't know much about the subject matter going in beforehand like I did. The dialog and jargon around the game can be confusing, and you'll likely not know what's going on because of it. The game tries to combat this by giving you a glossary when opening the menu, and updating it with terms bolded in-game whenever you encounter them. It still doesn't help too much though, as I had to google some of it in order to really pick up on it. The game tries to combat this by giving you a tutorial video accessible when you first start the game, or on the extras menu. It's voice-acted which... which makes it really cringeworthy at times. It got annoying enough to where I quit out of it early because I didn't think I'd make it through. And finally, while the game has some nice music at times, at others... it sounds too stock-music-esque and a touch unfitting to really sell itself.

Still, this doesn't detract from the game majorly. At heart, the story is a simple one; someone who wants to make the most of their talent and is willing to risk their finances and reputation to pursue it, even in a field where fame and longevity is uncertain. Make no mistake; though the game can be a bit silly at times, it doesn't treat its subject matter in a non-serious way, and that gives the game a much-needed breath of fresh air that most visual novels recently can't give you. Also, it's free and has low requirements, so any competent computer should be able to run it.

18163257.review:
[h1]I'll be blunt, the game wasn't made for me per say.[/h1] 
Not a Starcraft player. Hell, my last serious RTS was Age of Empires 2, and that in of itself should normally make a specialized VN like this outside of my place to play, much less review. But hell, I gave it a try when it claimed I could make due without knowledge, and it did not lie. So if the only thing keeping you on the fence is whether you'll understand anything, relax. The game has a glossary, for crying out loud. 

Where else to rank it... Well, I'll be as blunt as I can be. It's a free Renpy VN, after all. 

Gameplay boils down to your typical faire of making choices at select points, as you might imagine. You can play as either a male or female lead, but it makes little difference. Still, props for the option even existing. My point is gameplay isn't the main focus here... Though I do hope to see innovation in anything going forward. 

Visuals are smooth, nice, and right where they need to be. Likewise on the sound, everything from silky smooth tones to alt rock, everything blends pretty damn well in setting the scene right where it needs to be for the player. The game also shifts to something different just enough times to keep the player surprised without becoming expected, which I applaud. 

Story and characters are compelling in their own way, too. Even without knowing squat about SC personalities, I was more than amused by the faces shown here. Even if half the fun was figuring out the archetypes early on, and watching how they'd be played out. Speaking of, game's clean. Save for a tame extra scene, there is no fanservice or anything of the sort, much less romance to worry about, so don't expect that. I will say I enjoyed what bonding scenes we did get, and caught myself questioning what relationships other characters had before I showed up... A mark of good narrative delivery in my eyes, considering I actually was interested. 

Three things of note. First, no auto/skip functionality, so prepare to experience SC for yourself... When you feel like you need 300 APM just to get anywhere. (See? Wouldn't have known that before this game. Ahem.) This is swiftly dealt with by the second note, that the game is... Relatively easy to get the good ending on. It's no Sakura Spirit, there are numerous choices and -presumably- bad endings, but ah... I didn't get one. Yeah, somehow I got what could only be classified as a good/true ending on my first run, blind. No guides, just two google searches to find out what the hell Protoss even played like (and learning they were expensive as hell) and another to look up a term. All I did was play smart with basic logic from what the game showed me, and things played out flawlessly. So either I'm a natural SC2 player in the making, or the game's rather easy to complete unless you're a bonehead with this sort of thing. Third and finally, I was outright disappointed the ending I got, well... Ended so soon. It's a short game. But. 

That is actually a good thing, I suppose. For as many minor (and they are minor) gripes as I have, they are tremendously outweighed by the positives the game provides. Hell, I'm listening to the credits song on repeat because it's just that good wrapping things up. The game's short, the game's small, but it's free and packed with personality and warmth. Let me put this in no uncertain terms, okay? 
[b]I actively want a bigger, more full, more packed sequel, and I want to pay for it. I want to see this story through to a full end, I want to watch these characters progress, I want more, and I want to support the creators for it.[/b]
SC2VN is a short experience, but it's one I don't regret taking in the slightest, and actively want more of.

18162261.review:
Starcraft II: Visual Novel is definitely an interesting tale of a game. I can say first and foremost that it achieves what it set out to do; inform people about just how rough the eSports scene can be. Before anyone get's scared by this game being too heavy about eSports or Starcraft, don't be. It has an excellent glossary to help you with terms being used. As well as a cute, voice acted intro by Day[9] (a popular Streamer & Starcraft II commentator.) On the other hand, if you're a big Starcraft eSports fan, then you'll instantly recognize some players & personalities which are homages to other popular figures from the eSports scene. As well as some call backs to old strategies that were once viable in the competitive scene. Unfortunately this game doesn't have any branching paths, and choice isn't too much of a factor with a very short story. Simply talking and listening to your team's advice can get you the "good" ending without having any real prior knowledge of Starcraft. This game is also built on Ren'Py so you can litterally run it on just about anything.

18155526.review:
I have to say, this is one of my favorite premises for a visual novel ever.

I wasn't really into starcraft personally; I've played for a bit and I know the basics, but my RTS of choice was always Company of Heroes. As great as it is, is too beholden to an attempt to maintain historical accuracy to become an esport. But, I love the esports community; I'm engrossed specificlly in the Smash circuit, doing locals and following the exploits of legends like Mango, Hungrybox, and Mew2King. In those regards, I can easily relate to the culture of the scenerio, while also exposing differences in how certain comptitive circuits.

For a free game, this is actully pretty damn good. I love the art style, and the designs of the characters are really distinctive and good-looking (I especially like female Mach and Jett's designs). The characterization is a little one-dimensional, but then again the game is short and free; they only have so much time they can focus on. The music is ok; didn't really like the credits song to be perfectly honest, but the other songs combine electronic beats that mirror the Starcraft soundtrack almost perfectly.

I also loved the Day9 cameo and how Jett was basiclly a genderswapped IdrA (definitly my favorite character in the story by far). I knew enough about starcraft to appreciate those. The extra scene also shows how much love the developers have for the series, pointing out many other nuances that completely went over my head.

My biggest problem, is that the game feels, and I quote what I told a friend, "more railroaded than transport tycoon". There's no branching paths, no romance, nothing that really involves meaningful player interaction in the visual novel. Even the starcraft playing segments is a binary "win-fail" choice, leaving the player to have very little agency in the story as a whole. Yes, I know this a debut, free game, but it really kills any interest in replaying in the game. There's so little choices, there's only two bad ends that I even know of, near the beggining of the game!

In all, this is a solid effort and I think most elements of what makes a good visual novel is there. Before playing, I probably wouldn't have bought it if I had to pay for it, but afterwards I'd be more than glad to have the option of supporting the developers. If the hinted at sequel happens, I really hope that the game becomes more interactive. Let the player specialize in strategies, make matches actually engaging, manage relationships, or even offer a zerg/protoss route if all things fail, SOMETHING which allows the player to influence the game.

If you're on the fence, I reccomend giving this a shot. It's free after all!

18154497.review:
In SC2VN you play as Mach - a male or female (yes you get to choose the gender at start) Terran player who has a grandmaster status in the online ladder, but lost the qualifiers to VSL (I believe it to be ESL). So he/she goes to Seoul, Korea, to try vs some of the best and learn. And then it begins....

Let's take a look at the good about this novel, and the bad. I will do my best to leave any spoilers out. I will, however, say that I've played through this novel twice before it came to steam - its existence was well known to SC2 fans well in advance and many wanted to try it out - as it was kickstarted and the author made it clear that it will be free for all (SC pun intended).

The Good:

1. A valid representation of the international Stacraft scene.
2. Good writing and pleasant pictures to look at.
3. The writer obtained permission from Blizzard to use the Terran Starcraft + Brood War music, which I really love.
4. Any fan of Starcraft will easily recognize that the fake player and team names actually have real ones behind them, often with a single letter or so swap. If I am not mistaken (as I watch SC2 matches only leisurely and for fun), VSL is ESL, Enoch is Epoch, Jett is probably IdrA, Accel should be Flash, etc.
5. You get to play matches, and even have choices how to proceed, which will determine its outcome.
6. Over 2 hours of "gameplay".
7. It's FREE!!!


The BAD:

1. Some strategies used on the screenshots are clearly outdated.
2. There could have been more choices during the matches.
3. Some gameplay representations are not close to the reality (even in my meager knowledge from watching ESL games and other streams).
4. I was hoping for a more in-depth, action ending, but it is serviceable and fits the story well.

There is absolutely no reason why you shouldn't download and play this free visual novel. It's nice, it's well written, and it portrays the Starcraft universe both in-game and outside of the game really well with all the trash talkers, nice guys, events, and so on. It is nice short experience that in my opinion, one shouldn't deny oneself. Download it, read through it and have fun :) And... maybe read through it again, like I am doing now... for the third time...
